If

K

The following theorem characterizes equivalent absolute values. 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 Absolute values, valuations and completion, https://www.math.ethz.ch/education/bachelor/seminars/fs2008/algebra/Crivelli.pdf

absent = B _ d _ 2 * open-interval@(x, r ^ (1 / s))
absent = B _ d _ 2 * open-interval@(x, r ^ (1 / s))

An absolute value
| ⋅ | : K →
R
≥
0
is said to be non-Archimedean if

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@(x + y) less= list@(maximum@(absolute-value@(x), absolute-value@(y)), x), y element-of K)

para.p:
An absolute value is called Archimedean if it is not non-Archimedean. For example, the absolute value on the field
R
is Archimedean, since, for example,
|
+ 1 1
|
= 2 >
max
{
| 1 |
,
| 1 |
}
= 1
.

p.text:
If
K
is a field and
v
is a nontrivial valuation on
K
, then

The fact that

p v

p v
is the unique maximal ideal of
O v
. ∎

The above ring
O v
is called the valuation ring. Generally, a ring that has a unique maximal ideal is called a local ring, and thus the above theorem shows that the valuation ring is a local ring. We call the quotient
/
O v
